contextId.information: Here darkness and the shadow of death are spoken of as if they were people who could claim something as their own possession. The word "it" refers to the day of Job's birth. (See: [[[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: May darkness and the shadow of death claim it for their own

contextId.information: "terrify that day." The day is spoken of as if it were a person who could be terrified by the darkness. (See: [[[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This darkness is again spoken of as if it were a person who could grasp and hold the night. AT: "may thick darkness make it disappear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]]).
The night of Job's birth is spoken of as if it were a woman. AT: "may no child be born on that night" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]]).
This describes the dead stump as if it could smell water to represent water being near it. AT: "even if only a little water is near it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: even if it only smells water

contextId.information: This describes "iniquity" as if it were a teacher and Job's mouth is described as if it is learning. This means that his speech is greatly influence by his iniquity. AT: "your iniquity is like a teacher and your mouth is like its student" or "it is because of you sin that you speak the way you do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "throws itself at him" represents the wind blowing strong against him like an attacker. AT: "It blows strong against him like someone attacking him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]]

The deep waters and the sea are presented as if they are people that could speak. AT: "Wisdom is not in the deep waters under the earth, nor is it in the sea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The deep waters ... say, 'It is not in me'; the sea says, 'It is not with me.'

contextId.information: Job speaks of his heart as if it were a person. AT: "I am troubled in my heart and the feeling does not end" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: My heart is troubled and does not rest

contextId.information: The morning stars are spoken of as singing like people sing. Possible meanings are: 1) the "morning stars" are the same as the "sons of God" in the next line or 2) "the morning stars" refer to stars in the sky (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: when the morning stars sang together

contextId.information: The waters are spoken of as being able to hide. During the winter the ice hides the water underneath it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
contextId.quote: The waters hide themselves and become like stone

contextId.information: Yahweh describes the donkey as though he were a person that had a house. "I gave him the Arabah as a place to live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: whose home I have made in the Arabah

contextId.information: Yahweh describes the donkey as though he were a person. The donkeys laughs because those in the city have to hear loud noise, but he lives in quiet place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
The word "Aha" is a sound people make when they discover something. The horse makes a sound because he has discovered the battle. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
The author speaks about the hills as if they were people capable of giving him food. AT: "Food grows on the hill for them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: the hills provide him with food
